items.title: Fix simple typo: satifies -> satisfies
items.body:
There is a small typo in flask_api/request.py.
Should read `satisfies` rather than `satifies`.

items.title: handle_api_exception doesn't use custom app.response_class
Support Markdown 3+
items.body:
Fix this error:
> ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'headerid(level=2)'

as noted in https://github.com/flask-api/flask-api/issues/21#issuecomment-439355032 and update this commit: https://github.com/flask-api/flask-api/commit/de1a55d2469a624b0f4dc16609c3ed30e2566e9f.

items.title: It's not compatiable with Flask-RESTful
Flask-API can't parse request longer the 64KB
items.body:
Flask-API multipart/form-data parser does not set buffer_size and hence relies on default value from werkzeug which is 64KB.

**Flask-API:**
https://github.com/flask-api/flask-api/blob/8dfff5db4722e898167784826d3a94b70a380c04/flask_api/parsers.py#L39

**Werkzeug**:
https://github.com/pallets/werkzeug/blob/8eb665a94aea9d9b56371663075818ca2546e152/werkzeug/formparser.py#L285

That is enough for most, but not all the applications.
I suggest to set buffer_size equal or larger to content_length.

items.title: No content responses should accept not only an empty string
items.body:
Is confusing, specially when trying to keep consistence beetwen returned data types,  that to be able to send a 204 HTTP status code is needed to pass only an empty string not being valid and empty dictionary or None value for example.

Could be more flexible to support other "empty/no content" values.

items.title: how to avoid redirect?
items.body:
I setup a basic route with a get URL works from browser but using curl i just get a redirect link ``` curl "http://localhost:5000/parse?sentence=stufff" Redirecting...

Redirecting...

You should be redirected automatically to target URL: http://localhost:5000/parse/?sentence=stufff. If not click the link.% ``` I tried also with `app.run(debug=False)` but still getting this. Is there another switch somewhere that flips from the "browsable API" to something for production use?

items.title: basic docs on URL formats
items.body:
hi! I haven't used the Django framework before, so I'm new to this... but i've used a lot of frameworks. I'm trying to figure out the basics here.
I'm guessing there are minimal docs since this is meant to emulate Django?

## how to read query params
looking here
http://www.django-rest-framework.org/api-guide/requests/#query_params

```python
@app.route('/parse/', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def parse():
    text = request.data.get('sent', '')
    blob = {
        'data': request.data,
        'params': request.query_params,
        'hello': 'world',
        'text': text
    }
    print('blob', blob)
    return blob

app.run(debug=True)
```

gives error:

AttributeError: 'APIRequest' object has no attribute 'query_params'

items.title: v0.7.0 release breaks expected behavior
items.body:
One of the chief reasons we use FlaskAPI at Qualcomm is because of how easy it makes returning JSON content from a simple function.  However, it seems something between v0.6.9 and v0.7.0 broke this behavior; if you try to return data that isn't a `dict` or `list` from a Flask handler, you get a `text/html` response back, whereas you used to get an `application/json` response back.

In v0.6.9:
```
[pkrizak@balthasar]$ curl --include --insecure https://10.52.252.96:3519/api/v1/mapping/test_mapping/key1
HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json
Content-Length: 8
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Server: Werkzeug/0.12.1 Python/3.5.3
Date: Tue, 11 Apr 2017 03:40:13 GMT
Connection: keep-alive

"value1"
```

In v0.7.0:
```
[pkrizak@balthasar]$ curl --include --insecure https://10.52.252.96:3519/api/v1/mapping/test_mapping/key1
HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 6
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Server: Werkzeug/0.12.1 Python/3.5.3
Date: Tue, 11 Apr 2017 03:45:21 GMT
Connection: keep-alive

value1
```

It's OK if the new behavior is intentional -- if so, just please provide a way to get the old behavior back, because we are depending on it.

items.title: Transfer this repository
items.body:
@tomchristie has [expressed interest](https://github.com/tomchristie/flask-api/pull/75#issuecomment-292074313) in transferring this repository to a new owner. While I'm happy to adopt it (as the primary maintainer right now), I thought I'd poll the audience.

😄 : transfer to @jacebrowning
🎉 : transfer to a new `flask-api` organization
❤️ : search for an existing organization with similar goals
😕 : none of these

items.title: HTML form action misses prefix when using DispatcherMiddleware
items.body:
When using DispatcherMiddleware to mount an API app under a path prefix the generated HTML forms  contain wrong paths in the form's `action` attribute.

The reason for that is that `request.full_path` is used in the template which [doesn't include the `script_root`](http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/0.12/api/#flask.Request.url). The easiest fix would probably be to just use `request.url`.

items.title: JSONRendered to use app's json_encoder
items.body:
It would be good if one could change the default json_encoder class used for serialization. The one which is currently used is `flask.json.JSONEncoder`.  Trying to change it like so 
```
app = FlaskAPI('the_app')
app.json_encoder = CustomJSONEncoder
```

does not have any effect.

https://github.com/tomchristie/flask-api/blob/1.0/flask_api/renderers.py#L15

Wouldn't something like
```
        return json.dumps(data, cls=current_app.json_encoder, ensure_ascii=False)
```

instead of 

```
        return json.dumps(data, cls=JSONEncoder, ensure_ascii=False)
```

solve the problem?

items.title: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'replace'
items.body:
The example (http://www.flaskapi.org/#example) shows that an empty string can be returned for `DELETE` on a resource:

```
@app.route("/<int:key>/", methods=['GET', 'PUT', 'DELETE'])
def notes_detail(key):
    ...
    elif request.method == 'DELETE':
        notes.pop(key, None)
        return '', status.HTTP_204_NO_CONTENT
```

But with Flask 0.11 and Flask-API 0.6.6 this consistency causes this exception:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".../Flask-0.11-py3.5.egg/flask/app.py", line 2000, in __call__
    return self.wsgi_app(environ, start_response)
  File ".../Flask-0.11-py3.5.egg/flask/app.py", line 1991, in wsgi_app
    response = self.make_response(self.handle_exception(e))
  File ".../Flask-0.11-py3.5.egg/flask/app.py", line 1567, in handle_exception
    reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)
  File ".../Flask-0.11-py3.5.egg/flask/_compat.py", line 33, in reraise
    raise value
  File ".../Flask-0.11-py3.5.egg/flask/app.py", line 1988, in wsgi_app
    response = self.full_dispatch_request()
  File ".../Flask-0.11-py3.5.egg/flask/app.py", line 1642, in full_dispatch_request
    response = self.make_response(rv)
  File ".../Flask_API-0.6.6-py3.5.egg/flask_api/app.py", line 58, in make_response
    rv = self.response_class(rv, headers=headers, status=status_or_headers)
  File ".../Flask_API-0.6.6-py3.5.egg/flask_api/response.py", line 17, in __init__
    content = renderer.render(content, media_type, **options)
  File ".../Flask_API-0.6.6-py3.5.egg/flask_api/renderers.py", line 112, in render
    mock_content = html_escape(mock_content)
  File ".../Flask_API-0.6.6-py3.5.egg/flask_api/renderers.py", line 20, in html_escape
    text = text.replace(char, replacement)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'replace'
```

items.title: AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'items'
items.body:
Related to #58,  I am now hitting a spot where `blueprint_handlers` and `app_handlers` are both empty tuples with Flask 0.11 and 0.11.1, so the fix in #59 actually causes a new issue:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".../env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 2000, in __call__
    return self.wsgi_app(environ, start_response)
  File ".../env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1991, in wsgi_app
    response = self.make_response(self.handle_exception(e))
  File ".../env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1567, in handle_exception
    reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)
  File ".../env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask/_compat.py", line 33, in reraise
    raise value
  File ".../env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1988, in wsgi_app
    response = self.full_dispatch_request()
  File ".../env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1641, in full_dispatch_request
    rv = self.handle_user_exception(e)
  File ".../env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask_api/app.py", line 97, in handle_user_exception
    for typecheck, handler in chain(blueprint_handlers.items(), app_handlers.items()):
AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'items'
```

items.title: Incompatibility with flask .11 error handling: TypeError: 'type' object is not iterable
items.body:
Flask 0.11 Changed the order in which errorhandlers are executed and they added the type of the error handler in there making any app that registers flask-api to throw an error before being able to execute the proper error handler (app.py line 91)

What seems to work for me is to add the following in app.py:91

```
for typecheck, handler in chain(blueprint_handlers.items(), app_handlers.items()): 
```

since blueprint_handlers and app_handlers are now both `dict` objects

items.body:

``` python
notes = {
    0: '购物',

}
```

I get an exception: `UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe8 in position 16: ordinal not in range`

items.title: Towards 1.0
items.body:
I've been doing some preliminary work on a new Flask API framework. Given that I've never maintained Flask-API, and it's only ever been a very weak port of a few bits of REST framework, I'm strongly considering using this project for the latest work, and releasing it as a 1.0 version.

I'm really pleased with the incoming work, which is super simple, but features automatic client libraries & command line tool, plus schema generation in a nice & agnostic way (so, eg provide Swagger, API Blueprint, or any other schema type documentation out of the box)

I figure it's worth raising the issue here to see how folks would feel about an incompatible 1.0 release, if it was something that was actually going to push things forwards and be a release that I was actually using and significantly invested in for a change.

Any thoughts?

items.title: Request.parser_classes and Request.renderer_classes are hardcoded to be default
items.body:
This looks like a very strange hard-code of the request's configuration:

``` python
    def preprocess_request(self):
        request.parser_classes = self.api_settings.DEFAULT_PARSERS
        request.renderer_classes = self.api_settings.DEFAULT_RENDERERS
        return super(FlaskAPI, self).preprocess_request()
```

so it makes it impossible to extend the Request class and set it's classes attributes to a different from default values

items.title: Gui POST button not sending correct Content-Type header
items.body:
When browsing a CRUD interface, the POST (gui) action is sending Content-Type as a parameter: _content_type in addition to the payload, in addition to _content. This isn't working currently, and is never reaching the appropriate JSON endpoint causing 400 Bad Request to be returned.

Expected to see either:
1. Content-Type header set by Javascript at the frontend for the request
2. FlaskAPI parse the _content_type and _content params in the POST, and redirect to the appropriate target

items.title: Excluding some routes?
items.body:
Is it possible to exclude some routes from the web browsable API view? I wrote a web application with Flask that uses a few routes such as "/" to serve the web app page. Other routes like /api/<function> make up the underlying api that it uses.

Since this displays the API view when I go to the "/" route, my web app page is prevented from displaying, so I need a way to exclude those page view routes.

items.title: Incompatibility with the Flask-CORS extension
items.body:
I have been trying to combine Flask-API with the Flask-CORS extension in order to use it as the backend for a Single Page Application.

I've created a simple application to illustrate my backend here: https://gist.github.com/benjaminsims/6d51751b40e44eae1dcd

When I make a request to this server by doing:

```
curl --include -X OPTIONS http://127.0.0.1:5000/   --header Access-Control-Request-Method:POST             --header Access-Control-Request-Headers:Content-Type  --header Origin:www.examplesite.com
```

I get the following error:

Error on request:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/private/tmp/werkzeug/werkzeug/serving.py", line 181, in run_wsgi
    execute(self.server.app)
  File "/private/tmp/werkzeug/werkzeug/serving.py", line 171, in execute
    for data in application_iter:
  File "/private/tmp/werkzeug/werkzeug/wsgi.py", line 697, in **next**
    return self._next()
  File "/private/tmp/werkzeug/werkzeug/wrappers.py", line 81, in _iter_encoded
    for item in iterable:
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable

If I add 'OPTIONS' to the list of methods supported by the route, this does not occur and things work normally as far as I can tell. However, this is not an option as it interferes with the authentication decorator (it causes OPTIONS requests to return 401 Unauthorized).

If I alter the code to use standard Flask rather then Flask-API (https://gist.github.com/benjaminsims/7f8dbe99d004ca446e53.js) then OPTIONS requests work normally.

I'm therefore wondering if this is an incompatibility between the two libraries that needs to be fixed, and more generally if there is a better way to get CORS working with Flask-API.

items.title: New maintainer?
items.body:
@tomchristie has mentioned in #31 and #32 that he is not currently maintaining this project. I'm interested in helping support a `0.6.x` release with bug fixes. Can we talk about which of these options is best to move forward on this repo:
1. contributors create pull requests and @tomchristie merges
2. add additional collaborators with push permission
3. transfer ownership of this repo to someone else
4. create a GitHub organization for this repo and add collaborators to that

items.title: TypeError with query strings in Python 3
items.body:
With `Flask-API==0.6.2`, visiting a URL with a query string causes a `TypeError`. Browsing `http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/?foo=bar` produces:

```
...

  File ".../env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask_api/request.py", line 171, in full_path
    return self.path + u'?' + self.query_string
TypeError: Can't convert 'bytes' object to str implicitly
```

items.title: BrowsableAPIRenderer does not escape angle brackets
items.body:
If you have an Flask-API view that returns JSON containing angle brackets, like this...

```
 {"test": "I <3 Python"}
```

The angle bracket is not encoded as a <kbd>&lt;</kbd> (or <kbd>&gt;</kbd> in the case of a greater than angle bracket) entity in the HTML source code.

(I know from the README that the project isn't being maintained, but filing it for future reference. :smiley:)

items.title: [question] What is the difference between using httplib's constants vs. the status constants
items.body:
Thanks so much for building this. This will be incredibly useful.

I'm curious: what is the difference between using the named constants in `flask_api.status` and the constants in `httplib`? Is there a need for both?

items.title: Allow custom template when inheriting BrowsableAPIRenderer
items.body: It would be useful to be able to inherit BrowsableAPIRenderer and set a different jinja template.

items.title: Allow formatting the docstring with markdown
items.body:
As in:

```
def my_api_resource():
    """":markdown
    # this is my resource documentation
   parameters:
   - bla bla bla
   - foo bar
  """
  return [{...}]
```

Create a template tag or filter to detect the presence of ":markdown" in the start of the **doc** to format in template using flask-mistune

items.title: Use jquery.jsonview to format the result
Detect when HTMLRenderer is appropriate
items.body: After a glance on the web I expected Flask API to be a drop-in solution to add an API functionality to my app. However, it is necessary to add the `@set_renderers([HTMLRenderer])` before every view. Isn't it possible to make it implicit for functions returning an already rendered template?

items.title: Support for Flask MethodView
items.body: Flask-API doesn't work with Flask's `MethodView`.

items.title: Using with a Blueprint
items.body: Does Flask-API supports blueprint? The example is only using the Flask initialization.

items.title: @set_renderers expects a list
items.body:
The docs for [HTMLRenderer](http://www.flaskapi.org/api-guide/renderers/#htmlrenderer) say to use this decorator:

```
@set_renderers(HTMLRenderer)
```

However, this causes `TypeError: 'type' object is not iterable`. Changing the above decorator to

```
@set_renderers([HTMLRenderer])
```

solves the problem. I presume this is a bug in which the implementation for `@set_renderers` does not match the intended API rather than a bug in the documentation, since the other examples imply `*args` and not lists, e.g:

```
@set_renderers(JSONRenderer, MyCustomXMLRenderer)
```
